title: Overview of the basic path drawing commands lines and curves

title: A path defines a set of lines and curves which can be visibly drawn on the Canvas.

inline_content.Text: A path defines a set of lines and curves which can be visibly drawn on the Canvas.

title: A path is not automatically drawn on the Canvas. But the path’s lines & curves can be drawn onto the Canvas using a styleable stroke. And the shape created by the lines and curves can also be filled with a styleable fill.

inline_content.Text: A path is not automatically drawn on the Canvas. But the path’s lines & curves can be drawn onto the Canvas using a styleable stroke. And the shape created by the lines and curves can also be filled with a styleable fill.

title: Paths have uses beyond drawing on the Canvas:

inline_content.Text: Paths have uses beyond drawing on the Canvas:

title: Hit testing if an x,y coordinate is inside the path shape.

inline_content.Text: Hit testing if an x,y coordinate is inside the path shape.

title: Defining a clipping region where only drawings inside the clipping region will be visible. Any drawings outside the clipping region will not be drawn (==transparent) – similar to CSS overflow.

inline_content.Text: Defining a clipping region where only drawings inside the clipping region will be visible. Any drawings outside the clipping region will not be drawn (==transparent) – similar to CSS overflow.

title: The basic path drawing commands are:

inline_content.Text: The basic path drawing commands are:

title: Description of the basic drawing commands:

inline_content.Text: Description of the basic drawing commands:

title: Begins assembling a new set of path commands and also discards any previously assembled path.

inline_content.Text: Begins assembling a new set of path commands and also discards any previously assembled path.

title: The discarding is an important and often overlooked point. If you don’t begin a new path, any previously issued path commands will automatically be redrawn.

inline_content.Text: The discarding is an important and often overlooked point. If you don’t begin a new path, any previously issued path commands will automatically be redrawn.

title: It also moves the drawing “pen” to the top-left origin of the canvas (==coordinate[0,0]).

inline_content.Text: It also moves the drawing “pen” to the top-left origin of the canvas (==coordinate[0,0]).

title: Moves the current pen location to the coordinate [startX,startY].

inline_content.Text: Moves the current pen location to the coordinate [startX,startY].

title: By default all path drawings are connected together. So the ending point of one line or curve is the starting point of the next line or curve. This can cause an unexpected line to be drawn connecting two adjacent drawings. The
context.moveTo
c
command basically “picks up the drawing pen” and places it at a new coordinate so the automatic connecting line is not drawn.

inline_content.Text: By default all path drawings are connected together. So the ending point of one line or curve is the starting point of the next line or curve. This can cause an unexpected line to be drawn connecting two adjacent drawings. The
command basically “picks up the drawing pen” and places it at a new coordinate so the automatic connecting line is not drawn.

title: Draws a line segment from the current pen location to coordinate [endX,endY]

inline_content.Text: Draws a line segment from the current pen location to coordinate [endX,endY]

title: You can assemble multiple
.lineTo
c
commands to draw a polyline. For example, you could assemble 3 line segments to form a triangle.

inline_content.Text: commands to draw a polyline. For example, you could assemble 3 line segments to form a triangle.

title: Draws a circular arc given a centerpoint, radius and starting & ending angles. The angles are expressed as radians. To convert degrees to radians you can use this formula:
radians = degrees * Math.PI / 180;
c

inline_content.Text: Draws a circular arc given a centerpoint, radius and starting & ending angles. The angles are expressed as radians. To convert degrees to radians you can use this formula:

title: Angle 0 faces directly rightward from the center of the arc. To draw a complete circle you can make endingAngle = startingAngle + 360 degrees (360 degrees == Math.PI
2): `context.arc(10,10,20,0,Math.PI
i

inline_content.Text: Angle 0 faces directly rightward from the center of the arc. To draw a complete circle you can make endingAngle = startingAngle + 360 degrees (360 degrees == Math.PI

title: By default, the arc is drawn clockwise, An optional [true|false] parameter instructs the arc to be drawn counter-clockwise:
context.arc(10,10,20,0,Math.PI*2,true)
c

inline_content.Text: By default, the arc is drawn clockwise, An optional [true|false] parameter instructs the arc to be drawn counter-clockwise:

title: Draws a quadratic curve starting at the current pen location to a given ending coordinate. Another given control coordinate determines the shape (curviness) of the curve.

inline_content.Text: Draws a quadratic curve starting at the current pen location to a given ending coordinate. Another given control coordinate determines the shape (curviness) of the curve.

title: context.bezierCurveTo(control1X, control1Y, control2X, control2Y, endingX, endingY)

content_resolved.code: context.bezierCurveTo(control1X, control1Y, control2X, control2Y, endingX, endingY)

title: Draws a cubic Bezier curve starting at the current pen location to a given ending coordinate. Another 2 given control coordinates determine the shape (curviness) of the curve.

inline_content.Text: Draws a cubic Bezier curve starting at the current pen location to a given ending coordinate. Another 2 given control coordinates determine the shape (curviness) of the curve.

title: Draws a circular arc with a given radius. The arc is drawn clockwise inside the wedge formed by the current pen location and given two points: Point1 & Point2.

inline_content.Text: Draws a circular arc with a given radius. The arc is drawn clockwise inside the wedge formed by the current pen location and given two points: Point1 & Point2.

title: A line connecting the current pen location and the start of the arc is automatically drawn preceding the arc.

inline_content.Text: A line connecting the current pen location and the start of the arc is automatically drawn preceding the arc.

title: Draws a rectangle given a top-left corner and a width & height.

inline_content.Text: Draws a rectangle given a top-left corner and a width & height.

title: The
context.rect
c
is a unique drawing command because it adds disconnected rectangles. These disconnected rectangles are not automatically connected by lines.

inline_content.Text: is a unique drawing command because it adds disconnected rectangles. These disconnected rectangles are not automatically connected by lines.

title: Draws a line from the current pen location back to the beginning path coordinate.

inline_content.Text: Draws a line from the current pen location back to the beginning path coordinate.

title: For example, if you draw 2 lines forming 2 legs of a triangle,
closePath
c
will “close” the triangle by drawing the third leg of the triangle from the 2nd leg’s endpoint back to the first leg’s starting point.

inline_content.Text: For example, if you draw 2 lines forming 2 legs of a triangle,
will “close” the triangle by drawing the third leg of the triangle from the 2nd leg’s endpoint back to the first leg’s starting point.

title: This command’s name often causes it to be misunderstood.
context.closePath
c
is NOT an ending delimiter to
context.beginPath
c
. Again, the
closePath
c
command draws a line – it does not “close” a
beginPath
